name: Restrike: Holland Celebrates American Independence
obverse: Two female figures (The Dutch Maiden or possibly the goddess of war Minerva on the left and a Native American woman representing America on the right) shake hands over a pedestal with a caduceus and cornucopia. The Dutch Maiden uses a staff to place a Phrygian cap on America’s head. America holds a shield with thirteen stars and has her left foot on the head of a chained lion (Britain). The rear end of the lion is still upright.
obverse_inscriptions: MEDAL STRUCK BY THE UNITED PROVINCES OF THE NETHERLANDS 1782 IN HONOR OF AMERICAN INDEPENDENCE
reverse: A mountain rock on the left. A unicorn with a crown around its neck is lying next to the rock, its horn broken off and lying on the ground. It is implied that the unicorn rushed at the rock.
reverse_inscriptions: PRESENTED BY THE HOLLAND SOCIETY OF NEW YORK JANUARY 1904.
description: This medal was a restrike of the original medal minted in 1872 commissioned by the Holland Society of New York.
